instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .

threads.title: Bad <SIGNAL>CPU_VIDSCLK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello,

I come today with this board with which I measured good values everywhere.
Only <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is not present

So I made the measurements of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> which should send to <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> 0v OK
<SIGNAL>CPU_VIDSOUT</SIGNAL> 1.04v OK
<SIGNAL>CPU_VIDALERT_L</SIGNAL> 1.04v OK
<SIGNAL>CPU_VIDSCLK</SIGNAL> 0.365v INSTEAD OF 1.04V
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_ISUMP</SIGNAL> 0v INSTEAD OF 1.8V
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_ISUMN</SIGNAL> 0v INSTEAD OF 1.8V
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_ISEN1</SIGNAL> 0v INSTEAD OF 1.8V
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_ISEN2</SIGNAL> 0v INSTEAD OF 1.8V
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCSENSE_P</SIGNAL> 0v INSTEAD OF 1.8V
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCSENSE_N</SIGNAL> 0v OK

I replaced following the liquid damage <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>
Also catch-ups around the SMC

I don't have an oscilloscope unfortunately ...

thank you in advance for your help

threads.title: Bad <SIGNAL>CPU_VIDSCLK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> 0v OK"
OK???
You made other bad assumptions too.
But get enable signal for CPU power supply first...

threads.title: Bad <SIGNAL>CPU_VIDSCLK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
OK, that also seemed strange to me but it was the measure of a functional board ...
I will keep you informed
